dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frangois comes out of the café. Across the street, we discover a large building whose slightly outdated fagade is not particularly welcoming. He walks over to the imposing entrance that bears the shield of the City of Paris in wrought iron and beneath which we read “JAURES MIDDLE SCHOOL”. On the opposite sidewalk, coming from the other end of the street, a small group of teachers hurries towards the entrance. Frangois hears them joking.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: He’s a really great guy, not the back- slapping type but... Frangois greets them in passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We discover the school’s deserted corridors. Through the doorway of a classroom, Frangois sees a few cleaners who, in a very calm atmosphere, clean the tables and line them up neatly, wash the windows.. A short distance further on a man in overalls applies one last coat of paint to an administrative notice board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the principal in the meeting room, the teachers, old or new, introduce themselves briefly, as in a casting session.

dialogues.speaker: HERVE
dialogues.text: Hello, everybody, I'm Hervé. I’ve been at the school three years now. I teach sports. I’d like to welcome all our new colleagues. The students can be tough but they're good kids. There you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, everybody, I'm Olivier. I teach physical science and I've been here for 4 years.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I'm Patrick and I teach multiplication tables, and occasionally mathematics! I've been at this school for a number of years.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Anne. I used to work in the Lyon suburbs, in Bron to be precise, and I teach English. I'm looking for my new colleagues. Hello...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Hello, I’m Isabelle...

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. Hello...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIANE
dialogues.text: I’m Christiane...

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: I'm Frédéric, I teach history and geography and I used to work out in the suburbs of Paris, in Aulnay-sous-Bois if anyone knows it. I'm happy to be in the city now.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Julie, the year supervisor. I'd like to welcome you all and wish you a good year.

dialogues.speaker: ALINE
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Aline, I'm the cook and I'd like to welcome you all.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Aline.

dialogues.speaker: GILLES
dialogues.text: Hello, everyone. I'm Gilles, I've been teaching mathematics for many years now. I'm retiring at the end of this year. I'd like to wish the new arrivals plenty of courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Frangois. I teach French and I'm starting my fourth year here. Welcome, everybody. Then the principal hands out the timetables, eliciting a few sighs of satisfaction or disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the staff room, a new arrival listens to the succinct comments of an older member of staff, OLIVIER, on the different students in a second-year class as he runs through a list.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER
dialogues.text: Nice, nice, not nice, not nice at all... He's nice, not nice, watch him, not nice at all, nice, not nice, she's not nice at all. INT. CLASS —- DAY The children noisily enter the glass as Frangois looks on. The students take their places in general confusion, the girls on one side, the boys on the other. They show each other their new gear: pencil cases, brand-name exercise books.. Frangois, clearly used to this kind of agitation, raises his voice.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, all right, all right! Hey, hey, hey! Calm down now! Stop stirring things up there and remove your hood, please. You two back there, there's a place here. One of you comes up front. Things start to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Right, let's get one thing clear from the word go.. Hey! I want to get this clear from the start. We waste five minutes lining up outside, five coming up, five settling down: fifteen minutes out of an hour. Do you realize what fifteen lost minutes means? With twenty-five hours a week and thirty weeks in the year, we lose thousands of minutes. In other schools, they do a full hour. Imagine how far ahead they get in a year. Figure it out!  KHOUMBA, a girl with long hair in the style of Diana Ross, speaks up without raising her hand first.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: We never do an hour!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Put your hand up to speak. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: We never do an hour. You always say that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What do you mean, “we never do an hour”?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Teachers say we do an hour's class but we never do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: We never do an hour's class. We start at 8.30 and finish at 9.25. That doesn't make an hour.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, it's fifty-five minutes. Thanks, that's an important point.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: But we never do an hour. Stop saying other schools do an hour. They don't either.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, all I'm saying is that we waste time. Like right now. To start with, take out a sheet of paper, fold it in two so that it can stand on the edge of your desk clearly and, using block capitals, write your full name on it. While BOUBACAR sluggishly obeys, WEY, in the front row, translates the instructions into Chinese for his neighbor and shows her how to do it. A few rows behind them, ESMERALDA, Khoumba’s friend and neighbor, butts in.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Why do we have to write our names?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So I can get to know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know us!

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We had you last year.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Esmeralda, I don't know if you've noticed, but half of the kids here are new. So it can help. Be happy. This way, people will know your name.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I'm not doing it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I won't if you don't.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Ah, you have a point. For those of you who don't know me, I'm Mr. Marin.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Ms. Marin.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Hey, are you a marine?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: He wiped you out, that’s wicked.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: He didn’t wipe you out, he busted you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Come on, it shouldn't take so long. You should be a lot quicker. Five minutes to write a name. That's ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOPHIE, in passing, offers a biscuit to RACHEL and Frangois who is sitting nearby.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: A biscuit for the first day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mind one.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Rachel, a biscuit will buck you up.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Thanks. INT. CLASS —- DAY On the board, Frangois writes the words that the students haven't understood in the text that they are studying. A slightly affected student raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right... "Witty". That's a word we'll try to explain later. Are there any other words in the text that you don't understand? Burak.

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: The word "condescension". Frangois notes the word on the board, just under other more or less complicated words. He turns to the class.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: The word "condescension", yes, that's a complicated word. Do you have any idea, Burak, what that might mean? Any idea at all?

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: A vague idea but I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're not sure? All right, we'll talk about that later then. Yes, Damien?

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: "Argentite".

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Argentite. What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: It's people who live in Argentina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, exactly, the inhabitants of Argentina.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Wow, what a moron! Wicked!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Argentites and Argentitesses.. No, of course not. Damien, who lives in Argentina?

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: The Argentites.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, you know that's not right, you watch soccer on TV. Argentina's players are called...

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: Footballers.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Oh, what a big kid! A discreet-looking student raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Let's move on. Any other difficult words in this text? Henriette? Is there anything that you didn't understand? I imagine there is.

dialogues.speaker: HENRIETTE
dialogues.text: “Henceforth”.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: "Henceforth". Thanks for the prompt, Samantha. All right! I think that will do. Let's take a look at these words. All right. "Austrian".. Wey was the one who picked the word "Austrian". Yes, Esmeralda.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I mean, we all know what "Austrian" is. People from Austria.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, but Wey doesn't know and, well, Austrian isn't really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, but he's the only one, everyone else knows!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, we get the message. You didn't know "misleading", so you're not really in any position to talk about all that. We agree on that?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yes, but everyone knows what "Austrian" means! It's easy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Look here, nobody's perfect. Besides, "Austrian" is not a very important word. It refers to someone from the land of Austria, which is a pretty tiny country. We can live without the word. For example, can anyone name a famous Austrian? Not one hand is raised.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Mozart. “Wolfang” Amadeus Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What do you call him?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: “Wolfang” Amadeus Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: He could have been "Wolfang" maybe if he were English, not Austrian. Mozart was Austrian, yes, but do you know any other famous Austrians? So, basically, Austria could vanish from the map and no one would notice. But, seriously, it's a country south of Germany. So check a map, Wey. You'll see where it is. Souleymane, can you note the words too, like everyone else? Frangois’ blatant insincerity inspires a few collusive smiles in the class. Wey is delighted to have understood that his teacher is joking.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I forgot my things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no one can lend you some paper so you can do it?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay, I'll do it at home.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You'll do it at home. Sure you will. That's your approach. Not a stroke of work in class and everything done at home.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I'm serious. Don’t worry, it’1l be okay, it’1l be okay... Thanks. Souleymane, convinced that he has had the last word, seems fairly pleased with himself. Frangois turns to the list of words on the board again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, let's move on to "succulent". "Succulent" is a word that we'll try to guess the meaning of. What's in "succulent"? Suck...

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Suck off!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Jerk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Very funny, Boubacar. Very witty indeed.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: He should be sent out for that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I'll give you a sentence with "succulent". Bill enjoys a succulent cheeseburger. On either side of the word on the board, he writes a sentence: “Bill enjoys a succulent cheeseburger.” And he underlines the word “succulent”. A voice speaks out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CHERIF
dialogues.text: Cheeseburgers are crap, they stink.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Who said that?  10.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Cheeseburgers are the best.

dialogues.speaker: CHERIF
dialogues.text: I said it. Why a cheeseburger?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, since you say they stink, that means you think cheeseburgers aren't succulent.

dialogues.speaker: CHERIF
dialogues.text: I don’t care, but cheeseburgers are crap.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, but what I mean is, what I just said about cheeseburgers should have made the penny drop. Those who know become more and more impatient.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Sir, sir, what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What does what mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: The penny thing...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: "To make the penny drop." That should make the penny drop. No one knows the expression?

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A clue.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's it. If the penny drops, it means you're given a clue. When I say if Cherif thinks cheeseburgers stink, it means he doesn't think they're succulent, that should help you see what "succulent" means.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: What's with the Bills?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What bills?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Not bills, the name Bill.  11.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Bill and Ben.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: You always use weird names. Why don’t you use...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It's not a weird name. A recent US President was called Bill, remember.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Why don't you use Aissata or Rachid or Ahmed or...

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You always use whitey names. It’s wicked.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What names?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Honky names.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What's a honky?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Honkies, Frenchies, frogs. Frangois seems a little put out, as if he had been trying to avoid this kind of discussion.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're not French, Esmeralda?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: No, I'm not French.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Really? I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Well, I am French, but I’m not proud of it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Fine, I'm not either, actually.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Wiped him out!  12.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Neither am I, in fact, I’m not proud to be French either.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Why do you use these names then?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Khoumba, if I start choosing names to suit your different ethnic origins, it'll never end.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: But change them a bit..

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, Bill, Ben, Bob..

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Change them a bit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So what do you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Er, Aissata...

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mamadou, Bintou...

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Fatou. No, Aissata. Aissata!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the depths of his locker, Frangois finds a mandarin orange that seems to have been there for some time. Frédéric comes to sit down next to Frangois, a coffee in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Do you have class 4/3 in French?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm the class supervisor too.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Do you already know what book you'll be reading?  13.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, I haven't decided yet.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Because in history, I'll be starting with the Ancien Régime. If you want to link into that, what kind of books are there?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, there's the Enlightenment but that’s tough for them in their year.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: How about Voltaire? Is he tough?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, he's not easy.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: I don't know. "Candide" is an easy read...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Not in their year.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: “Zadig"..

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe, but it’d be tough. INT. CLASS —- DAY Frangois has bags under his eyes and seems to be having a bad day. Behind him, on the board, a verb is conjugated in the imperfect tense. The verb endings have been underlined. The whole class, silent, works on an exercise. Frangois seems to be miles away. His weary gaze sweeps over the class. All of a sudden, he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, in 20 seconds, we correct it.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: No, sir, please! We haven't finished. With some sweeping gestures, DALLA asks Rabah, in the opposite row, for the time. Rabah starts to reply with equally exaggerated gestures. Frangois seems to snap out of his daze and answers curtly.  14.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: We can't spend two hours on the imperfect. Dalla, you can ask me for the time if you want. With an involuntary wink, she signals to NASSIM whose pen has leaked over his jacket. Frangois, on discovering the scene, raises his eyes to the heavens in exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: NASSIM
dialogues.text: Sir, this crap pen keeps leaking! It's getting on my nerves.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Who has a handkerchief for.. Rabah takes a tissue out of his pocket and stands to take it to Nassim.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Me!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Rabah, Rabah... Ask before you stand, okay. Rabah sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: May I? In passing, Rabah trips over his neighbor's bag and stops himself from falling by grabbing Juliette’s shoulder, sprawling over her exaggeratedly. She pushes him away roughly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Gently, okay.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: The perv! He touched her tits! The perv!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Come on, just give him the handkerchief! Boubacar, spare us your comments.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Goddam pedophile! You big kid!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Sir, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... Quiet!  15.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You ain’t got a chick or what? You need to press up against chicks, Rabah!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hey, take it easy! Only Esmeralda doesn’t burst out laughing. She seems bothered by something. As she thinks, she ends up asking her question.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: (to Esmeralda) Yes...

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Sir, why do they say the imperfect indicative?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If you want chicks, let me know, I’11l give you contacts. Frangois seems happy that Esmeralda is so motivated. He speaks to her with gentleness.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Quiet, Souleymane! All right, Esmeralda, why the indicative? She raises her eyes to the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You're pushing it! If I knew, I wouldn't ask!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I can imagine. How about the others? Does anyone know why we specify the imperfect indicative? Why not just the imperfect? Nassim.

dialogues.speaker: NASSIM
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I go wash my hands because...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Go on, wash them and get it over with.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s gonna visit the corridors.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Make it quick!  16.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He'll be back in a week! I’m going with him!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, enough! If we talk specifically about the imperfect indicative, that means it's different than another imperfect. Which imperfect is that? Agam? AGAM answers calmly.

dialogues.speaker: AGAM
dialogues.text: The imperfect subjunctive.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Exactly. The imperfect subjunctive. Can anyone give me an example of the imperfect subjunctive? I don't believe it, Khoumba, go on.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Hold on, I may be wrong... Frangois gives her an encouraging smile.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so too.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I were.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I were. Of course, from the verb "to werr"?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No, I were.. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I wuz.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No, I were, you were, you were, they were...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right. That's not bad but you use it wrongly. You vaguely recall the imperfect subjunctive. Imagine I say: "He insists that I be" - let's say - "in shape." What is "be" in that example? Eva?  17.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: The present subjunctive.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Very good. For the imperfect subjunctive, we follow the sequence of tenses and use a past: "He insisted..."

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: He insisted... he insisted that I be.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: "He insisted that I..." Khoumba?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Were.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Were, yes!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You really think I'll tell my mom. "He insisted that I were'd been in shape?" And that she'll understand?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Not "I were'd been". Learn to use it before you start complaining.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: He insisted that I were'd been in shape.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: "That I were in shape". Use the sequence of tenses.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: But no one says that in real life, it's true, it's true!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I was right! "I were"!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, will you let me answer the question that you asked me? If you care.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yes, you may.  18.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: The first thing I notice is, before mastering something, the imperfect subjunctive, you're already telling me it's no use. Start by mastering it, then you can call its use into question.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Sir, why are you criticizing us?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: They're right, it's not the way people talk now, that's the way they talked in the old days. Even my gran didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Or your great granddad. It's from the Middle Ages!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, it’s not from the Middle Ages and for starters

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: It is!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Of course it is!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: It's bourgeois.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Tell me, when was the last time you heard someone talk like that? When was the last time you heard someone talk like that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yesterday, with friends, we used the imperfect subjunctive... (he is briefly interrupted by jeers) All right, all right.. Can I reply?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Yep!  19.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I'm ready to talk this over, but calmly. All right, it's true not everyone talks that way. In fact, people who do are pretty rare, I'll grant you that. I'd even say only snobs use the imperfect subjunctive.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: What's a snob?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Snobs are slightly affected, slightly precious people who tend to put on airs. He makes an precious gesture with his wrist. A student’s voice rises up from the back of the class, convinced that he has found the answer.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Homosexuals? This remark makes Frangois smile.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, not homosexuals. You can be affected and refined without being homosexual, Boubacar. In any case, what I see is that this register may seem formal and a bit affected and even bourgeois. But the important fact is these different registers exist as I keep telling you, and as I shall carry on telling you, I think. You need to be able to use them all: familiar, current, formal, oral and written Move between them and use them all. Yes, Lucie?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIE
dialogues.text: How do we know what's for written and what's for oral?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Why is a word more for one register than the other? Normally, that's something that you pick up as you go along. You need to use intuition.

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: What’s intuition?  20.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Intuition is when you can't use thinking. When you can't really... It's not knowing but more like sensing something. That's it. Intuition is when you sense things.

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: What if you don't sense them?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: If you don't sense them, well... You gain intuition by using the language. That's when you learn to distinguish almost automatically between oral and written styles.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Sir, Souleymane wants to say something.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth! Shut it!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What does Souleymane want to say?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: But... please... okay... say it!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What is it? What? Calm down!

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: If he says it, you'll tell.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Cut it out! No fighting!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I'll whop you!

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Go ahead, bro, just quit playing the tough guy! Frangois is surprised to see Souleymane, who has been talking with his neighbor for the last few minutes, with his hand raised.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Souleymane, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I’1l whop you one!  21.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Boubacar, turn round. Boubacar, turn round. What is it, Souleymane?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Boubacar, who seems to know what his friend’s question is, takes over from him.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Say it, bro.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Apparently something is up.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Don't send him to the principal if he says it.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: If I tell you, I'm good for Guantanamo! Frangois takes an obvious pleasure in pushing Souleymane who, himself, is having fun upping the stakes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS
dialogues.text: (as one) Guantanamo, Guantanamo, Guantanamo!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Forget it, I'll be tased.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, you won't be "tased", as you put it.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What is it? You have a question?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So ask it.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: It's too wicked. It's too wicked!  22.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, it’s not too wicked.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: But it's the pits for you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Look, now we've come to this, just ask it!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I have your word?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hurry it up!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I don't know.. This is what I heard, okay? I didn't say it but I heard... People say you like men. I didn't say it!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Who says that?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Well, just people, see..

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: They say Mr. Marin likes men and all that. Different reactions in the class. We hear laughter and cries of surprise. Frangois smiles as if he had been expecting this question sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay. So others say that, not you?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, you’re not interested? Souleymane squirms on his chair, smiling awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, I don’t give a damn.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So why ask the question then?  23.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: It’s for the others. I'm a spokesman.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: But the question doesn’t interest you at all?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn. If you like men, fine.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Exactly! Unwilling to back down now that he has come this far and perhaps basking in the prestige that he is acquiring with the rest of the class, Souleymane insists:

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: So is it true or not?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So you are asking me!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Homosexual isn't an insult, sir. It isn’t an insult.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You say it isn't but it seems to be a problem for you. You find it odd, men liking other men.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Maybe it is, I don't know. But is it true or not?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, it's not. Feel better now?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah? Sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Sorry to disappoint you. That’s how it is. Souleymane simply pouts dubiously.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Wiped him out big time!  24.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, if Souleymane doesn't mind, now he's settled his hang-ups, let's get back to the imperfect indicative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a high angle, we see the students horsing around during the break. Souleymane is taking photos with his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Change the pose, change the pose! Yeah, like that! Not bad. Go on, move. Hey, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Cut it out, please!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: What’s up? Who asked you? Look at your mug!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Hey, give me a break, it’s fucking okay! Take these jerks, then we'll see.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Go on, show me your backs. Yeah, one more, go on.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Wow, that’s a classy display.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You bet!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Got one for me?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You can't afford it.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: How much is it?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Too much.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Stop thinking I'm broke like you.  25. INT. CLASS —- DAY Justine comes up to the board, looking a little worried. Her classmates stare at her as if she were climbing the gallows. She hesitates for a second but then picks up the chalk and takes the plunge. She starts declining a verb, making a mess of it, then hurriedly erases the word that she has just written. The suspense is perceptible. Justine ends up turning to Frangois.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Hold on, that’s not it.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: She screwed up there. She thinks it's a regular verb.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: No, the verb's "swim". Swimmed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Quiet!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: I swimmed.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Justine... Swummed!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Justine, work it out yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Swammed!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Swummed. That's better, it mixes the two!

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: It’s swammed, it’s swammed!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: That’s not it!

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: It is!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She put swemmed.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Shut up! Swammed is...  26.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Try swommed!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, thank you, you can sit down.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You big kid! Swommed!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Let's see...

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: She can't write!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: She can't write? Can you, Rabah?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: You bet!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Go on then. Conjugate it properly. Correct her.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: First, swimmed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, carry on. Cut it out, the rest of you!

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Swammed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Wrong again.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: He sucks.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Just kidding. That's not what it is. It's not like that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So what is it?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: S.W.. Without an "I".  27.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Right, no "I". Why make fun of Justine, when you can't do any better than she can?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: I can.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: At least Justine got off to a good start... (to the rest of the class) That's enough now!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: What’s up, sir?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Can I explain something to you?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: It’s swammed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What I'm seeing here, is that you can't focus for more than 20 seconds, like 3- year-olds. People aged 13, 14 or 15 like you're supposed to be.. If I ask a question, they should answer fast and then we waste no more time.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Your kidding around goes too far!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Not at all, I don’t think I go too far.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Everyone thinks you go too far. Sorry but...

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I think so too!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Just a second, Khoumba. Everyone thinks so or only you think so?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: No, everyone!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Speak for yourself for once.  28.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Everyone thinks so and I think you push it too, I mean, what is this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I’m ready to cut you some slack and leave you right where you are...

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Teach is spitting hate!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: «but you'll never get anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: That’s no reason to push it too far! That’s no reason to push it too far!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It is. That’s exactly why, the reason I just gave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent bursts into the staff room that is particularly calm today. He sits down and starts to complain.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I'm sick of these clowns! Sick of them! I can't take any more! They're nothing, they know nothing, they look right through you when you try to teach them. They can stay in their shit! I'm not going to help them. They're so basic, so insincere, always looking for trouble. Go ahead, guys. Stay in your crap neighborhood. You'll be here all your lives and it serves you damn well right! I'll see the principal and tell him I'm not working with 3/2 again. No more technology for the rest of the year. Too bad. It's been three months now and they haven't done a single thing! Have you seen them in the yard? It's like they're in heat! They're all over each other like animals. It's crazy! It's the same in class. Kevin spent a whole hour going... "duh, duh, duh." I've never seen the like of it in 5 years. Enough! No more. We're not animals. Sorry, I'm. It's dumb.

dialogues.speaker: HERVE
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's get some air.  29. INT. CLASS —- DAY It’s cold outside. The students, in their winter clothing, seem very excitable. On their desks, we see “The Diary of Anne Frank”. Some of them read the first few pages of it amid the general hubbub.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: One extract isn't a lot to read for today. No one did it? We're wasting a crazy amount of time here. Okay, let's read it or reread it then. Who wants to read? Great.. Excellent work atmosphere today! Khoumba, go on.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I‘m not reading!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you’re not reading?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to read.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So the class revolves around your desires now?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I don't want to read!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I don’t care if you don’t want to read! Khoumba’s sole reply is a sneering sound that immediately annoys Frangois. He addresses the other twenty-four students as witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What did Khoumba just do? Wey?

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: Sneer.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, I meant her attitude. What did she show? They all think hard.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Insolence.  30.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, that's right, you're an expert.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: You're standing there, all angrulo with me! What is this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I'm not, that's not true. And try saying it in French. What am I?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: “Angrulo".

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Say it in everyday French, please.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: You're wired at me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's normal French?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: You've got it in for me! Frangois is clearly spoiling for a fight and doesn’t want to leave it at this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Not at all, I just want you to read. And I think I have the right to ask you to read, don't I?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You don't think so?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No. No one has read it and you're picking on me! What is this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Not at all, I’m not picking on you. I want to work and I've chosen you...

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: And I have the right to as your French teacher.  31.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Just drop it, I said! Drop it!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Shut up now! We’re listening!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure! No way, I’m not reading. You tell me to shut up, then to read. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What’s what?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Make your mind up! Think it through! Frangois has heard enough.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, you can come see me after class and we'll talk it over. It won't be fun.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Yeah, great!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You won't say that later. All right, Esmeralda, are you on strike too or can you read for us?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: It's her life. I don’t give a damn.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Very good. In that case, will you read for us?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I'd be delighted to!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, Esmeralda, we're listening. While Esmeralda reads the extract, the other students listen more or less attentively. Khoumba, on the other hand, seems as furious as before.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: "Dear Kitty, I'm known as a bundle of contradictions. As I've told you several times, my soul is split in two. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On one side, my exuberant cheerfulness, my mocking approach to everything, my joy in life and my ability to take things lightly. By that, I mean not seeing any wrong in flirting, giving a kiss, embracing someone, or telling a tasteless joke. That side lies in wait, pushing back the other side which is more beautiful, purer and deeper. The truth is that no one knows Anne's better side and that's why most people can't stand me. I can be an amusing clown for an afternoon, but then everyone has had enough of me. So the nice Anne has never once been seen in company. But, in her loneliness, she always triumphs. My best to you. Anne Frank. Anne's diary ends here."

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Anne Frank's diary ends here. Why? Because the police turned up at the rooms where Anne Frank's family was hiding and deported them all. Anne Frank died shortly after. That's what I asked earlier and what we've talked about several times already. When I read this, I learn about Anne Frank because she talks about herself and so I get to know her. When I ask you to write your own self-portraits, I'll expect the same. In other words, to learn things through your feelings. You can also talk about facts that will allow me to know you better. Yes, Lucie?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIE
dialogues.text: What we write won't be as gripping as... as what Anne Frank wrote. Our lives aren't as gripping.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right... Juliette?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Well, someone aged 70 could talk about their life, but we have nothing to tell at 13.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I don't know, at 14, 15 or even 13, you've had experiences.  33.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Less than a man or a woman aged 70. They've lived a lot more, they're nearly through...

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They have more to pass on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It's funny. Basically, you don't think your lives are interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir. What do we do? We just come to school, go home, eat and sleep.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Really? You come to school, eat, sleep. Fine. Okay, so the bare facts of your life are dull. But what you feel, Angelica, that's what's interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: But that's my business.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe, but I'm interested.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Yes, but you’re different.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Why am I different? I perfectly normal.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Because you're a teacher, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: But this isn't the teacher talking.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: It's your job.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You could say it's the human being.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: Okay, but well... I think you're only saying that to get us to talk and stuff but it's not true.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Really? What isn't true?  34.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: The fact that you're interested in knowing all that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So you think I'm lying, that I'm not interested in you at all and that I'm pushing at this to convince you it's interesting?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: No, it's not that but it's not as interesting as you say.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Maybe I am exaggerating a little. It's only natural since you don't agree with me. But, deep down, I'm totally sincere. Why is it such a problem for you to talk about your lives? Boubacar?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Well, there's stuff.. There's private stuff.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. What could be hard to say about your private lives? Burak?

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: Well, we may be ashamed to say certain things.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, it has to do with shame. There are things you find it hard to say and even harder to write maybe.

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: And... in your life, your personal life, when were you ashamed?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: You can be ashamed of a pal's mom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Ashamed of a pal's mom. Why? Because you find her ugly?  35.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: No, it's not that. For instance, Rabah's mom. She offered me lunch at his place but I refused because I was ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You were ashamed to eat with Rabah's mother?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Because you think she’s unworthy of you?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Tell me why, Boubacar.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: I'm ashamed to eat in front of her because I respect her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So, you never eat in front of people you respect?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: No, it's not that. I mean, she's not my girlfriend!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So you can only eat in front of your girlfriend? Tell me why, Boubacar. I'm interested.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: I can't explain it. In any case, I'm ashamed... I always hang out with Rabah, so I respect his mom. I don't eat in front of her, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So we'll know now that if Boubacar eats in front of us, it means he doesn't respect us.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: No, it's not that! You can't understand. You can't understand.  36.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I can't understand, I'm not smart enough?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: No, it's not that. You just can't understand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Rabah.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: The other week, I was at a party with nothing but Camemberters.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Nothing but Camemberters?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, like you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Remind us what a Camemberter is.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Someone who stinks of cheese.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So you went to a party where everyone stank of cheese?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: They were all in suits and ties. I was in my baggies and got these weird looks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: And you were ashamed?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Because of the looks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Basically, they were embarrassed in front of you and so you felt embarrassed in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: No, they weren't embarrassed. They looked at me like I was an E.T.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But you are an E.T.!  37.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: “Why's that Arab here?"

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, so it was a race thing or something...

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: I don't know.. I don't know. But the snacks were bacon-flavored.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So? Is that...

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: So I... abstained.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Right. Bacon, ham. Okay, I get it. Wey?

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: Young people these days have no shame.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Young people now?

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Like you, for instance?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Gimme a break! Drop your briefs!

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: You see, they have no shame. It's normal. Always normal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Are you like them, Wey, or do you feel shame?

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: No, I’m not like them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You feel shame from time to time?

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: Yes, shame for them.  38.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth! I'll waste your ugly mug! You should be ashamed, looking the way you do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Anyone can speak but you stay polite, okay. So, Wey, why are you ashamed for them?

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: They have no shame. They yell, they hit each other. They make jokes, bother others. No shame.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: But, Wey, aren't you confusing shame and discipline? You find the others rowdy and impolite?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It can be shameful, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, that can be shameful too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: You can be ashamed of your appearance.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Absolutely. You can be ashamed of your appearance. Tell me, Louise, are you ever ashamed of something physical?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: My ears.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Your ears?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can we see them?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're ashamed of your ears? What's wrong with them?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: They stick out.  39.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You think they stick out. Okay, well, I think that covers it all. You have all you need to figure it out. Take out your exercise books. Note the following exercise for next Thursday. It's very simple: "Write your self-portrait." Remember a self-portrait isn't an autobiography. I don't want your life story. Describe yourself and your personality. We'll read them in class and see how we can use them. Don't forget.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Goodbye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Hey, just a second, Khoumba! You know I want to see you. Give me your report book.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Why? Khoumba tosses the report book at him, which he doesn’t appreciate.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You know why. No, give it to me. Politely. That's enough now. Put your photo on it someday. Is it normal to refuse to read when a teacher asks you to? Is that normal?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: There's others in the class!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Just because you're not the only one who screws up doesn't mean I can turn a blind eye to this. Does it?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What happened this summer? What happened during the vacation?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I didn’t see you during the vacation.  40.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I know you didn't. That's why this is a problem for me. At the end of the year in June, we'd gotten on pretty well together. You participated in class. Since September, since the start of this year, you're not cooperative, you keep sulking, you refuse to read, etc, etc... What happened?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I just don't like reading anymore. Can you hurry, please?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, I won't hurry! Explain. Why have things changed all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I can't stay a kid forever.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So it's a kid thing to cooperate? So that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I don’t like reading anymore.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: There's others in the class.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Of course, when you work, it's.. I'll give it back when I've finished. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: But I’m in a hurry, my mom's waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Maybe, but I want an apology first. An apology for what you did. "I apologize for being insolent, sir."

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Sorry. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, not "sorry". "I apologize for being insolent." Go ahead.  41.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I apologize for being insolent, sin...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, "I apologize for being insolent." But be sincere. I want a real apology.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Can you hurry up, please? My mom's waiting. Maybe you have plenty of time...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Your mother can wait. She’s waiting for you to apologize. This is the ideal moment. I want a sincere apology that'1l stand for the rest of the year. We won't go on like this.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I apologize for being insolent to you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: More conviction!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Hey, come on.. I'm not saying it 50 times!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You two! What are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Nothing. We’re waiting.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Sure, sure...

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hurry, I'm listening!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I apologize for being insolent. May I go now, please? Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You joker!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Cut it out! Khoumba has spoken mechanically, with a total lack of conviction.  42. Frangois ends up handing her report book back. She takes it and skips over to the door. Just as she is about to vanish off along the corridor, she turns to Frangois and exclaims.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You wiped him out big time! Way too wicked! Frangois leaps up from his desk but it’s too late. The girl has already vanished off along the corridor, to the giggles of her friends. Frangois kicks a chair in annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s night time. We are in the meeting room. The tables have been set out in a U-shape. Five or six teachers, a member of the school’s administration, parents’ representatives, two students (a boy and a girl from year four) are present.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Two weeks ago, at the last meeting, the teachers suggested introducing a penalty point system for the students based on the driving license system. If students broke a rule, they would lose points. As it's the teachers' idea, I'll let them speak.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANE
dialogues.text: Since last September, we've noticed an increase in problems within the school. Punishment has no effect on the students. So we had the idea of a penalty system. The students would have, for example, six points each and, depending on the misdeed, they'd lose one or two points. PARENTS’ REP #1 And when they run out of points?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANE
dialogues.text: When they get down to zero, they go before the disciplinary committee. PARENTS’ REP #2 As a parents' representative, this is typical of the school's bad habits. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARENTS’ REP #2 (CONT'D) You always condemn the students but never praise them.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: But they earn praise on their own. They do it with their grades, by moving up a class and we do it in staff meetings by encouraging them to work if their grades are below average. Then there's the honor roll, the congratulations... That all counts! BURAK’S MOTHER In your system, you take away points for misdeeds but why not go further and give points to those who do good things?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Like gold stars!

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I'm all for praising the students but if students collect points and end up with 34 points, say, that leaves room for all kinds of trouble we can't control.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Without going as far as these imaginary 34 points, six points to start with means they can cause trouble without punishment. I'm sorry, but losing a point or two isn't a real punishment. It can create a dangerous sense of impunity. For me, the idea's totally wrong-headed.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: In that case, we could find a punishment where the students lose all their points in one go. But why bother with the points in that case?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: That’s the whole problem.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: It’s not simple.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You know, what you call a sense of impunity gives us room to maneuver. When you're dealing with punishments that are cut and dried, you can't adapt them to each case.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: No, I don't agree. The rules apply in the same way to all the students. They break them, they're punished. If not, why bother with rules?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Maybe, but dealing with extremely strict rules creates the greatest tension. Take cell phones, for instance. We agreed on a rule that cell phones were not allowed in class. Well, sorry, but I break that rule because I realized it wasn't a problem for me. There's room to maneuver, to be tolerant.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Sure, that's the reign of the arbitrary.

dialogues.speaker: FARIDA
dialogues.text: No, the law and the spirit of the law.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Now then, I know we could talk all night but that's not possible. We have other topics to tackle. In particular, one vital issue, a very sensitive one, concerning the coffee machine that the teachers have asked to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It's a sensitive issue, all right! Everyone agrees there's a real problem with the coffee machine this year. The price of a coffee has gone up from 40 centimes to 50 centimes. That may seem petty but since we drink several coffees a day at 8, at 10 or at 4 in the afternoon, it works out at a lot. So we've clubbed together to buy a coffee maker. That way, we can drink as much coffee as we want without having to count.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Monsieur Pierre will be delighted to reply. Monsieur Pierre, the bursar, starts speaking shyly. All the same, we can tell that nothing will stop him.  45.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR PIERRE
dialogues.text: Yes. First of all, I'd like to remind you that this machine was installed in 2001 to replace a machine that needed the intervention of an outside company for restocking, repairs, etc. It was very expensive and not at all profitable. We switched to the new machine which isn't profitable yet.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that! Used to the bursar’s endless speeches, the people present exchange embarrassed looks that Monsieur Pierre, his eyes glued to his notes, haughtily ignores.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR PIERRE
dialogues.text: And so we increased the price of coffee by ten centimes to fifty centimes. There. The thing has to be economically viable.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Isn't anyone shocked by this?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: It's clear and logical to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gathered around a meager buffet, all the people attending the meeting sip champagne. Frangois quickly slips out to smoke a cigarette in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Frangois alone, walking down a long, dark corridor as the sounds of the small party fade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes open the door of the staff room. Two CLEANING WOMEN who were chatting peacefully pick up their gear and apologize. Frangois tells them that they can stay, but the two women have already slipped out into the corridor. Frangois opens his locker and pulls out a pile of papers on which the mandarin orange is balanced. Frangois puts the fruit back in the depths of the locker and automatically sniffs the first sheet before reading it. It’s the work that he gave Khoumba as punishment.  46. We can just make out the title, written in block capitals: “RESPECT”.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Respect." #Adolescents learn to respect their teachers little by little because of their threats or the fear of having problems. For starters, I respect you and respect must be mutual. For instance, I don't say you're hysterical, so why do you say I am? I've always respected you so I don't understand why I have to write this. In any case, I know you have it in for me but I don't know why. I have decided to sit at the back of the class from now on to avoid any other conflicts, unless you come looking for them. I admit I can be insolent, but only if I'm provoked. I won't look at you again, so you can't say my look is insolent. In theory, in a French class, you talk about French, not your grandma, your sister or girls' periods. And so, from now on, I won't speak to you again. Signed Khoumba. INT. CLASS —- DAY Khoumba’s voice continues over this next scene. While Frangois is at his desk, the students work on their self- portraits with more or less care. Some have “The Diary of Anne Frank” open on their desks. Others daydream or chat in low voices. On the blackboard, we can read, “I work on my self-portrait”. Frangois goes from table to table, advising the different students.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Why are you hiding it like that? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: It's a secret.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: A secret? It won't stay a secret for long. Esmeralda, why have you changed places?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: No reason, I just wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Is there a problem?  47.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: No, not at all. No problem. I just wanted a change of scene. He turns to Khoumba who immediately looks away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, that's enough. Let's get to work.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: No, sir, please! Please, sir!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're just copying what you did at home. You've had plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: That's right, that’s right but, sir, we have to do it neatly here. Please!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Esmeralda, we're listening.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Huh? I have to?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: My name is Esmeralda Ouertani, I'm 14 and I live at 9, Allée du Pére Julien Dhuit, Paris 20, with my two parents and my three brothers and sisters. Later, I'd like to be a policewoman because people say all policemen are bad and so we need good ones. If not, I'd like to be a rapper and I'ma fan of Bakar, Médine, Younes, Marvin and Mafiak'l Fry. Otherwise, I like eating, sleeping and hanging out in the ‘hood.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, or rather?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: The neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, so why don't you change it since you know how? When you write, you use the standard style. Don't wait until I correct you. Wey, go on.  48.

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: All right. My name's Wey, I'm Chinese, I'm 15, I have two sisters, I'm the youngest. My hobby is playing video games, at least 4 hours a day. I find it hard using French correctly. It's so hard expressing myself that others don't understand me. That's why I don't communicate much. I hardly ever go out. Nothing much interests me outside. The environment doesn't suit me here since I'm allergic but I don't know what.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Allergic to yourself, that's why they can't find what you're allergic to!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's good, Wey. I feel that I know you better after hearing your self-portrait. That's the goal. To tell us things.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It just happens to be good when it’s him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: His just happens to be good, not ours. Ours never are.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, not at all. If Wey's work is good, I congratulate him. And I'll gladly congratulate you if you've managed to do it well. That's the truth... In fact, Rabah, you can read us your self- portrait.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: No, I’m not reading.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So how can I congratulate you if you don't?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: I don't need that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well make your mind up!  49.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You want compliments.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Go on, we're listening.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: My name's Rabah, I'm 14, I listen to rap. I love my village in Kabylia and go there every year. I like music, rap and slam. I have two brothers but I don't like school. I don't like tramps. I like Zidane, I like to talk and I like Psy 4 de la Rime's videos. Go Marseille!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: We can manage without Marseille.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Go Paris, you mean!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: We don't really need it in a self- portrait.

dialogues.speaker: CHERIF
dialogues.text: Sir, he didn't read it all! He skipped two lines!

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: That's all! I read the lot!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hey, cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Go, dude!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Boubacar!

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: "I like to make love".

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: I never wrote that!

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: "I like to look good for the women and I like summer to see girls' cleavage."  50.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, all right. (reactions from the other students) Why not, Rabah, why not?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: I never wrote that! I won't say who did.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It looks a lot like your writing though.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: My writing? No way.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It does. But there's no shame in liking cleavage.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Is this my writing? Frangois looks around the class. His gaze settles on Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It's not a sin. Souleymane, stop rocking and read your self-portrait. I'm curious to hear it. The adolescent, sprawled on his chair, sits up straight, taking his time.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, not huh.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I didn't write anything, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: But I’m sure you did, I saw you writing earlier.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, I wrote nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Nothing!  51.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: We're listening.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I'm Souleymane. I have nothing to say about me because no one knows me but me. After a moment’s silence, Frangois says ironically.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: (calming the jeers of the other students) Okay, okay, enough.. That's good. A bit long maybe. How come you can't make the effort that the others did?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I don't like talking about myself, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: How come the others make the effort and you don't?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Well, if they do, that's their problem. I don't talk about my life, okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Really? This leads to a little laughter. Esmeralda can’t stop herself from making fun of Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: It's not that he doesn't want to, he just can't write, that's all!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: What's up, you cop? You want to be a cop and you're talking to me? Goddam cop!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I can live with it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right, that’s enough!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Get lost, cop. Arrest guys instead of talking to me. Got your cuffs?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Chill, French guy.  52.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Your breath stinks!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Chill, okay.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Heard of Aquafresh?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Souleymane, Souleymane, there's no need to be offensive.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I can lend you a toothbrush if you want!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, cut it out. Souleymane, you're a lot better at oral insults, you're great at that, but when it comes to writing, nobody's home.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: He can't even write his name. Souleymane’s sole reply is to point to a tattoo in Arabic that he has on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Zip it! What does this say?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Go on then, the same old shit with your Koran. Souleymane becomes indignant.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth. What's wrong with the Koran? I'll spare you my "shit" when you calm down!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Go on, piss us off, that’s from the Koran?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hey, calm down.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: It’s the Koran so shut your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Stop making this crap up!  53.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I’m not making it up! Frangois comes over and tries to see the tatoo.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What's that tattoo, Souleymane? Why are you showing it to us?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: He says it's from the Koran but that’s not for sure!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hey, hey! What is it? What is that tattoo? Why are you showing it to us?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: It's nothing, it’s nothing! Boubacar comes to his rescue.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: It means shut your mouth, shut your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You shut your mouth! That’s not what it means!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So give us the right translation. Go on, tell us.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I don't want to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You show it in my class so you're going to tell us what it means. Souleymane hesitates for a second.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: It says here, right here: "If your words are less important than silence, keep quiet."

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: That’s what I said!  54.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, that’s not what you said.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Hey, Rabah, isn’t that what I said?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, it’s not what you said.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Why isn't it the same thing that Boubacar said?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's different. I think it sounds better.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, it's better put. Souleymane, if only you could write as interesting things on paper as on your arm, that would be great.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I think so too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That proves you can do it. Right, after these first few self-portraits, I'd like you to rewrite them and polish them, making sure you answer the questions that we listed at the start of class: what I like and don't like, my qualities and flaws, who I'd like to be.. (a knock on the door) Come in!

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Good morning. The principal has come to introduce a new student, CARL, to the class. On seeing that the students aren’t going to move, the principal sets them straight. They stand reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Stand up, please. Good morning. That goes for those at the back too. Come on, stand up. Chérif, did you hear me? Everyone has to stand. It's simply a way of greeting an adult. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It doesn't mean submission or humiliation. All right. Sit back down. I've come to introduce a new student. Carl. Try to make him welcome until the end of the year. Thank you. Goodbye. Frangois gestures to the classroom. As the principal goes back out, the new students sluggishly takes his place as the other students look on, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Goodbye. Carl, go sit in the third row, in that free place. Khoumba, can you move your things? Take a sheet of paper and a pen and try to catch up with the others. We'll talk after. (the bell rings) Don't forget the homework for Monday without fail. Let's finish with this. Goodbye. Carl, stay here a minute or two.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Adios, sefior. INT. CLASS —- DAY As the other students leave the classroom, Frangois signals to Carl to wait. The boy looks a little worried.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Welcome.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now that the other students have left, Frangois adopts a more confidential tone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I don't know if you know but I'm Mr. Marin, your French teacher and your class supervisor. So if there's a problem, you talk to me about it. I know who you are. I mean, I know why you're here. The principal told me but that doesn't matter. We'll start from scratch here, okay? It will all go well. You've seen that we.. We're on self-portraits to be handed in next Monday. Maybe you could do one too. You know when the next class is? Carl looks awkward.  56.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Monday, at 9.30.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, Monday, at 9.30, very good. All right.. And do you like French?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes, like everyone, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean much. Okay, off you go.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Goodbye. You know what a self-portrait is, that’s not a problem?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes, have a good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One evening after the day’s classes, Frangois, sitting at his desk, sees the students’ parents one by one. We see a series of portraits of the students’ parents. Some defend their offspring tooth and nail, others demand greater severity with their children and others still seem totally indifferent to what Frangois has to say. WEY’S PARENTS seem to be concentrating hard and hanging on Frangois’ every word but the looks on their faces show that they don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Good evening. Pleased to meet you. WEY’S FATHER Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
