dialogues.text: Sit down, please. Thank you for coming. I know it isn't easy. Well, we're very pleased with Wey. Very pleased indeed. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANgGOIS (CONT'D) All the teachers at the staff meeting said so. He's kind, he's pleasant... It's good to have him in class. And it's showing in his grades. We have.. the usual good grades in mathematics. He's doing well there. 13/20. In French, we have a 9 here... WEY’S FATHER Not a lot. Meanwhile, Wey’s mother looks on, a big smile on her face. She clearly doesn’t understand what is being said but has a vague impression that Frangois is speaking favorably about her son.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, he doesn't speak French very well yet but that's only normal. He talks a lot. He tells me about a lot of things. He talks about his computer. He's into that. WEY’S FATHER Yes, yes, always too late.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You think he works too late? WEY’S FATHER Yes, too late, not sleep good. After, school not good. Eyes get sick after.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, his eyes.. In any case, he may spend a lot of time on the computer but things are fine at school for now. WEY’S FATHER Yes, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: He works well and he doesn't seem tired. WEY’S FATHER Thank you. Nassim comes next, with his FATHER

dialogues.speaker: NASSIM'S FATHER
dialogues.text: Nassim.. I'd like him to do.. He can go far. He has all he needs. At his age, I wasn't that lucky. I'm right behind him. Anything he needs, I get him, no problem. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NASSIM’S FATHER (CONT'D) But he has to do right. It's true, things are good at home with him but I'd like him to keep on studying.. and go far. Me and his mother, we'd like to be proud of him. That's what we ask of him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I think we all agree on what we need to do. It's crazy how alike you are.

dialogues.speaker: NASSIM
dialogues.text: We're lookers in the family, only natural.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, you're right. The next parent is ARTHUR’S MOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: So an adolescent who talks with his family, who has good grades, who has friends, even if he's a bit of a loner, he's an outcast? He's a boy who talks with adults, who exchanges with them. Maybe he doesn't with you but that means he's just a teenager trying to define himself, that's all. I was useless at school for years. I rejected the idea of making us fit in with the system. Do his black clothes bother you? The way he looks? I don't get it. Then comes Burak’s mother (seen at a meeting earlier), with her son. BURAK’S MOTHER I'd like him to go to the best, to Henri Iv.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Henri IV? Why do you want him to go there? BURAK’S MOTHER Because...

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: Standards again.. Henri IV is all she thinks about. BURAK’S MOTHER Because they have very high standards. A mother always wants the best for her son.  59.

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: Yeah, my mother's scared I'll feel lost in high school because the others went to fancy private schools and Dolto High isn't as demanding so... BURAK’S MOTHER It's a pity that the teachers, well, maybe not the teachers, I don't want to accuse anyone... but the school...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Go on, accuse us. It's always a pleasure. BURAK’S MOTHER Why don't you try to push the better students a little harder, say? They get bogged down by other students who aren't as good.

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: My mom makes stuff up. Dolto High isn't useless. She thinks private schools... BURAK’S MOTHER I didn't say useless, I said average. I didn't call it useless. This stream of parents ends with Souleymane’s mother, accompanied by her older son, aged 17 or so. He is the one who speaks since his mother doesn’t understand a word of French.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: We talked about Souleymane a great deal at the staff meeting. Many teachers have complained about his attitude, which is very negative. Souleymane’s brother immediately becomes heated. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Many complain that he comes without his things. When he comes, that is, as he's often absent. He's often late too. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: In any case, I think you know that.  60. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER No, we didn't know. Souleymane tells us he works hard. A brief conversation with his mother in Malian. Souleymane’s brother becomes annoyed as he translates for his mother who also starts to get angry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Can you translate for me? SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER She.. she doesn’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: There have been notes in his report book since September, three months now. Notes about the problems he was having. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER She signs them without knowing because she can't read, see.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What about you? Do you read the notes too? SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Yes, but I'm just his brother. You see?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, but you knew there was a problem? SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER No, I didn't know. Whenever I ask, he says things are fine.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Do you see him work at home? SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER He stays in his room Sso..

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I see. Another conversation in Malian. Souleymane’s mother, as angry as before, starts talking curtly to her son. Frangois looks at them in surprise. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER She says she doesn't understand the notes in the report book.  61.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I realize that. In any case, you know the situation now. I'm telling you officially: there's a problem. You need to talk to him. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Yes, I'll talk to him about it, I'll talk to him about it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, just having a.. Maybe a conversation with his father could help too.. it would be interesting. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Yes, yes, I'll see, I'll talk to my father and see what we can do tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, we're not settling scores. We just want to improve things. He stands to say goodbye, shaking hands with Souleymane’s mother, then with his brother. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Another conversation in Malian. Souleymane’s mother has already turned to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students wait in the corridor outside the computer room. Souleymane is showing the others some photos on his cell phone. We see views of his apartment and of him clowning around with his friends. His classmates are impressed by the quality of the photos but start laughing when they see a photo of Souleymane’s mother, particularly tense and glum in front of the camera.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Is that your mom?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Shit, she’s an ugly old crow!  62.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth, your ma's ugly, and so are you.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: She sulking or what?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, she just hates photos. Me and my bro had pissed her off. Frangois comes up discreetly behind them and listens in on the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Let's get started. Boubacar, who has noticed Frangois, calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Hey, sir, look, Souleymane has brought photos for his portrait. A little embarrassed, Souleymane looks away.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Cut it out, my photos are crap, they suck.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's good! It's a great idea.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Get lost you! Get your own cell! Frangois opens the door and the students rush over to the computers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Painters do self-portraits. Photographers too.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yes, but too bad, I'm no painter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I know that. All right, let’s get started. Caps off, please. Hello...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I spend all my free time playing the guitar.  63. They are all busy typing up their self-portraits. Souleymane has taken out a cable and, crouching under the table, is looking for a free USB connector. Frangois is a little worried

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: If you're typing, hurry and finish to let the others type up their self-portraits. Souleymane, don't blow the place up!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, no, not right away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You know what you’re doing?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, since you're a computer genius, you can put it all back after.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I'm counting on you. Everything okay, Carl?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. In another corner of the room, Carl is typing something up. He doesn’t pay any attention to his classmates who treat him just as indifferently. Frangois comes up behind him and tries to read over his shoulder. Carl immediately turns his screen away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I’m not allowed to see it?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: No, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: How do you spell Lafayette?  64.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Like Galeries Lafayette.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Why are you mentioning that?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I go there often so I want to add it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's weird. I mean, it's four metro stops from here. You never usually leave the neighborhood, that's a huge leap in one go. Khoumba gets annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Hey, we're not hicks!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: We're city kids!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Really? You go into the center of Paris?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You bet!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I go everywhere. The lst, the 5th, the 20th, the 12th, the 19th...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Really? Why do you go to the 5th?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: In the 5th, I go to see pals in high school. Near Luxembourg.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I see. You go to the Luxembourg Gardens?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No, not the gardens, I said Luxembourg.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You go to the country called Luxembourg?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No, the Luxembourg metro station!  65. Frangois tries to changed the subject.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right. So you do get out and about. (a beat) I see you two have made up. That’s good.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: That's our business.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: And not yours.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: So, how do you spell Lafayette?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Lafayette is L-A-F-A-Y-E-T-T-E. With a capital. All of a sudden, things start stirring in Souleymane’s corner. Souleymane has uploaded his photos and more or less added them to his layout.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Yeah, they're much better now!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Much better.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: She looks good. Frangois comes over and looks at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, that is a good photo. Souleymane turns to the screen as if to check on what Frangois is saying.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: And now you could add a legend.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: A legend? Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Like a story or a tale.  66.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, not that kind of legend. A caption under the photo like in newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You mean, like in "Le Parisien"?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, like in "Le Parisien".

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What kind of legend could you put here? Who is this woman?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: My old woman.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: My mother.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, you could say she's your mother. Then you could explain why she's making this gesture of pushing away the photographer.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Him and his brother had just pissed her off.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna write that!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So why is she making that gesture?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: She hates photos.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So write that. "My mother hates having her photo taken." That's a legend, see?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.  67.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Then do that with all the photos and you're set.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Printed it all out?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I’m all set.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Great. This is perfect. Souleymane’s photos emerge from the printer, perfectly laid out and captioned. Frangois goes to pin them to the wall as Souleymane watches, suddenly intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: What are you doing now, sir?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: As you can see, I'm putting the photos up to get a global view. The others read out their self-portraits, so you're going to put yours on show. Souleymane looks more like an intimidated child than ever.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: My photos suck, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Not at all, they're very good.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Sure...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: And when a student does good work, I let the whole class see it.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You're just doing this to wind me up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, I wind you up if I feel you can do better. This is good.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: That's bullshit.  68.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: If you've finished, come and take a look at Souleymane's masterpiece. Slowly. We'll straighten them after. Souleymane, surprised at seeing his “work” on show like this, has the impression that he is naked in front of the whole class. The other students come over (only Carl continues to work on his text). They all make enthusiastic comments that Souleymane responds to with a great deal of false modesty. We can tell that he is both flattered and worried about revealing so much. As we hear the students’ comments, the camera shows us Souleymane’s photos in close-up: the members of his family, views of his neighborhood... he has often photographed himself too occasionally in everyday situations, but also at times from a more narcissistic angle with close-ups on his tattoos. INT. CLASS —- DAY

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I like playing soccer. I like playing computer games. I like playing with pretty girls. I like vacations in the Caribbean. I like fries, zouk and dancehall music. I like watching MTV Base and I like my parents and my brother. I like my pals and staying up all night. I like the TV series on the slave trade. I like my 'hood. I like the series "Homeland Security". I like eating in restaurants and going wild. I hate people crying for no reason. I hate techno and tectonic. I hate guys and girls who show off. I hate visiting my brother in jail. I hate talent contest shows on TV. I hate politicians, the war in Irag, Goths and skaters. I hate teachers who are too strict. I hate mathematics, racists and I hate Materazzi. I hated the Paul Eluard school and I like being here. The class is perplexed by this whole declaration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the staff room, Sophie discreetly takes a bottle of champagne out of her bag and pops it into the small fridge under the coffee machine. Behind her, the conversations are interrupted by the arrival of Julie, the year supervisor, who addresses the whole staff.  69.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Hello, I have something to say. Could you listen to me, please? Rachel, I have something to say. The mother of Wey, a student in 4/3, has been arrested. She was in France illegally. She has been picked up, she's in a holding center and may be tried next week. She could be deported back to China. I thought you should know as it's important.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: That's crazy, the family's been here 3 years now!

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Yes, I know but that's how it goes, wrong place, wrong time. The police turn up and she gets taken in.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: What about the father?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: The father doesn't have papers either but they're not bothering him for some reason. So, what I wanted to suggest, to start with, as lawyers cost a lot, we could do a collection and maybe even go to court to try to have some influence on the verdict. Julie puts an envelope down on the main table so that everyone can add his or her contribution. Sophie, standing near the fridge, looks awkward.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Will Wey have to leave too?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Not for now but you never know. A moment’s silence. Sophie decides to take the plunge. She takes the bottle out of the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Well, I feel kind of pathetic after that. I had something to tell you, but this isn't a good time.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You've said too much now!  70.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yeah! That calls for a celebration!

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Congratulations! The news is greeted with enthusiastic exclamations. Someone takes the bottle from Sophie, someone else hands out plastic cups, while Sophie, clearly touched by their reaction, sits down as if she were about to give birth. Rachel hands her a glass of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: How far gone?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Two months. I'll only have a drop. Just a drop. Vincent opens the bottle messily.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bravo, Vincent!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: He's an expert!

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I didn't do it on purpose! Who shook the bottle?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Here, Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Any ideas about names yet? If it's a boy, say?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: If it's a boy, I’d like to call him Enguerran.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Enguerran?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yes.  71.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It's good to give him a handicap in life. I mean, he'll have plenty of other advantages...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot! I hope not. You all have a glass?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Just a second...

dialogues.speaker: TEACHERS
dialogues.text: Cheers! They all raise their glasses. In the midst of this agitation, Sophie looks absent for a second. Then she too raises her glass to make a toast.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Right, I have two wishes. I have two wishes. My first wish is that Wey's mom can stay in France. And my second wish is that my child will be as intelligent as Wey. Cheers, everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a soccer match in the schoolyard. Carl seems to have found his place among his classmates. In fact, he is very sure of himself as he plays, monopolizing the ball with a great deal of ease. Souleymane tackles him and make him fall.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: (to Wey) Jackie Chan! Go for it! (turning to look at Carl) I didn't do nothing! I didn't do nothing! He just fell! He came at me, I never touched him.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hand! Hand! Thanks! Play, Souleymane!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Fucking go for it!  72. A few minutes later, Carl dodges a tackle by Souleymane and scores.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: What do you say now, Mali man?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: What's up, you Caribbean shit? Motherfucker! Let go of me, I'll waste the fucker! Caribbean fag! Let go of me! Shut your mouth! Go blow Thierry Henri, faggot! INT. CLASS —- DAY As the class settles down, Frangois explains the rules of the game to them. Nassim is impatient a hint of

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Stand there. Talk loud enough for them to hear and try to convince them. Go ahead. the first to react. He seems genuinely to express himself. He harangues the class with provocation in his voice directed at Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: NASSIM
dialogues.text: The Africa Cup of Nations will be starting soon. I'm glad Morocco's playing. It's the best team in the world in my opinion. The sick thing is that my pals, the Malians, aren't playing. It's tough for them. They weren't good enough to qualify. Morocco would have let them play on a friendly basis but 4-0 really hurts. As he speaks, Souleymane simply nods his head, as if to say, “Go right ahead...”

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What do you mean 4-0?

dialogues.speaker: NASSIM
dialogues.text: Last time Mali played Morocco, they wasted them 4-0. But the weird thing is when Mali doesn't play, it's like all the Africans here aren't African. With each cup, they all go crazy but when Mali doesn't play, they keep a low profile. Weird.  73.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So, whether Mali plays in the Africa Cup of Nations or not, the Africans in this class feel more or less African. Okay. Thank you, Nassim. I get the feeling your words are directed at your neighbor, Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Morocco jerk's not even on my radar.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Arthur is next. I see you have your notes, just like a politician.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, that’s good. Speak up, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You want a slap?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Esmeralda, let him speak before you judge him.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I want to defend the way I look because a lot of people say it sucks.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Right on, dude!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don't dis your clothes, so you don't dis mine. Clothes are freedom of speech. I dress how I want, you dress how you want, I say nothing to you, you say nothing to me. I dress like this to be different and not follow the others like sheep.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're the sheep here!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I feel better being myself and not being like others. I also think if there were 22 Goths in this class and one guy like you, you'd keep quiet then.  74.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Arthur, I think there's a contradiction in what you say. You want to be you. But are those clothes you? Those clothes are worn by a huge number of people.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Most people who wear them are gloomy inside so we're all kind of alike.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're all alike, you're all gloomy, so that's not you.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: No, by being different.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're different and the same. Thank you for taking a stand and being brave enough to do so. (a beat) Boubacar, go on.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Boubacar, my pal!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Quiet. Listen to him.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: I've come up to reply to Nassim. He says that since Mali isn't in the Africa Cup of Nations, black Africans have no team to support. But he's forgetting one country, Ivory Coast. With an ace player, Didier Drogba. Yeah, Didier Drogba. Didier Drogba beats any Moroccan. He plays for Chelsea. What Moroccan plays in England? They're not up to it. I'm through.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Thanks, Boubacar. I think that rectification was indeed... indispensable. Who wants to speak now? Carl, go on.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Actually, I'd like to say they're starting to piss us off with this Africa Cup. At break you're there, pissing us off with your cup. It hasn't even started yet...  75.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Carl, I'll be polite with you. Sorry to interrupt, but tell me, what's your national team?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: France.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Wiped him out!

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Look at the players on the team.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Why don't you say you're French in that case? Why do you say you're Caribbean?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: We are French. What’s your problem?

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Why don’t you say...

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Our Caribbean islands are French.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Why don't you ever say you're French instead of saying your Caribbean?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: It's the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: No, I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Look at the players we have. Thierry Henri, Wiltord, Abidal, Thuram.. Just look at them.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Where does Diarra play?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Diarra won't ever play in Mali, bro, he's not crazy enough.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth, pal, I'm telling you I'm not your bro! An ape like this jerk...  76.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No need to lose your cool.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Look at him, new here and already the big shot. Shut your goddam mouth.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: We can talk calmly! This isn't a slanging match. It's a debate. Souleymane, watch your language.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I‘ll get you, you Caribbean shit!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: He's fuming! Souleymane’s sole reply is to give her the finger.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Clam up. Go get fucked!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Enough of your vulgarity!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Know where you can put that?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: (to Frangois) I ain't talking to you, man!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, I'm talking to you! Esmeralda is splitting her sides.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: But, sir, he doesn’t know what he’s saying, just forget it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: (to Souleymane) Hey, is that any way to talk to a teacher?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: (to Esmeralda) Who are you talking to, dog-face? Shut your mouth!  77.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That’s enough now. Just get your things and come with me.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I’ll fuck you all!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hey! I’m talking to you!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Don't start yelling at me, okay. (to Carl) I'll get you, faggot.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You just can't talk normally, can you? Nobody else moves.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You calling me an ape? Fuck you, man!

dialogues.speaker: I/E. STAIRS
dialogues.text: They slowly come down the stairs. Frangois is seething. The teenager drags his feet, forcing his teacher to come back up a few steps from time to time. The scene resembles a silent duel. The crossing of the yard is just as laborious.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hurry it up! Move it! The teenager stubbornly continues to advance at his own pace.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Hey, get your hands off me!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Aren't you sick of assing around? These words have echoed around the yard. Frangois then notices that the other students are pressing to the windows of the classroom, watching them and laughing. Souleymane has noticed them too and stops to do up his shoelaces, just to show off. Frangois tries to recover his calm but we can tell that he is still on edge. He waits patiently for Souleymane. After taking his time doing his laces, Souleymane sets off towards the principal's office again.  78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the principal's office, they look each other up and down one last time, then Frangois knocks on the door. The principal tells them to come in.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Sorry to bother you. I have a troublemaker who's been disrespectful in class. Souleymane sits down almost instinctively opposite the principal's desk.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you to sit down, Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I have to get back to my class, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: I’ll see to this. Frangois leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Sit down now. All right, I'm listening. Will you tell me what happened? You think it's normal that a teacher should have to leave his class to bring you to the principal's office? The teenager seems determined to remain silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around a table set out in a U-shape, the class meeting brings together all the teachers that work with the class, members of the school’s administration and a parents' representative. As for the students, they are represented by Esmeralda and Louise who keep chattering together in low voices.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: "Results too uneven. Too much talking in class." Now let's move on to Louise, present here today.  79.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: The biggest disaster in the whole class. What can we do with you? No, good work!

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Always good, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Excellent and it's a joy having a student like her. We have to say so when it happens...

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: So, shall we offer this young lady a commendation?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I don't totally agree with you. She's relatively well-placed in the class from a numerical angle. But a commendation? There's room for progress, huge room for progress and I don't think her general attitude really merits a commendation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's the problem with commendations. Are they purely numerical and mathematical or are they also to do with her attitude and behavior as top of the class?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Hold on, that means, to get a commendation, you have to be an excellent student and, at the same time, be a class leader? No!

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Please, please!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: A commendation carries a certain weight!

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: So a commendation this term. Louise is intelligent and will realize she can do better to satisfy you. Now, Chérif. Our friend Chérif.

dialogues.speaker: HERVE
dialogues.text: I have a problem with Chérif. He's a kid with abilities, he could do well. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HERVé (CONT'D) I could easily give him 17/20 but he spends so much time talking and disturbing the class, his average grade is poor. And that's a pity.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: His behavior's irregular. He can be a disaster and you can't do a thing with him or he can be really good.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: So what do we put for Chérif? A warning about his work or his behavior?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: For me, behavior, not work.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: In my class, it's more his work.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: It's more like a work problem, looking at his grades. Mathematics: 6. French: 8. History and geography: 9. English: 9.5...

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: (hurrying out, splitting her sides) Excuse me!

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Science: 12. Music: 11.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: His grades are pretty low but I have the impression that it's more a behavior problem. Why don't we put that for now and say he can work harder?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: So I'll put, "Chérif can succeed as long as his attitude changes in relation to his work." Let's move on to Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Souleymane... Someone else can start. Knowing smiles around the room.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: What do we say?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Nothing good!  81.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I think we already discussed him in the first term. We said it all. He has huge weaknesses, notably in written French. I don't think there's anything particularly new this term. Esmeralda comes back in, having calmed down.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Feeling better, Esmeralda?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: I didn't know being class rep was such fun. We were talking about Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER
dialogues.text: In relation to what Frangois just said, he forgot his things most of the time this term and, I have to admit, didn't do much.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: But it's not just that, it's way beyond that. He's more and more unruly. He prevents the others from working. Esmeralda butts in, raising her hand to speak.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: May I say something?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Yes, Esmeralda, if you put the biscuits away. Remember, you aren't allowed to eat in a classroom.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Well, his overall grade has gone from 6.75 to 7.25... So...

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Yes, but we're not discussing his grades but his behavior for now.  82.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I have the impression we need to consider disciplinary action. His attitude's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It's simple. Every other class, I throw him out.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don't even throw him out anymore. He's only too happy when I do, so it makes no sense.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I don't think disciplinary action will help because things will get really bad then.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: They're already really bad! It's gone too far. It's like he's mad at the others for being normal students.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: I'll remind you, Mr. Marin, you brought him to me only yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, but it was this year's first incident. He was disrespectful, so I had to set a limit. I did what I did but I don't think it will go any further than that. Since the start of the year, I don't have any real complaints, apart from yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: But our job isn't to make sure students sit quietly at the back and don't cause any trouble. We have to bring these kids out! Esmeralda and Louise are amused by this lively discussion between two of their teachers. The principal looks as if he wants to take things in hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I won't do that with threats or punishment. I'd rather stress his good work because some things interest him. He can come out with some pretty good stuff.  83.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Simply because he does something positive now and then, we let him sink and wallow in his hole and we do nothing? You just want to buy social harmony.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: That said, what do we say? What do we do? A warning?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I don't think a warning's what he needs. Maybe we should say Souleymane has reached his limit because he's limited scholastically.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shit, that’s tough. He shouldn’t say a thing like that! Esmeralda and Louise pretend to be shocked by Frangois’ words but burst out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Okay, that's all well and good but I'm dim and have a line to fill. What do we put? Frédéric and Frangois remain silent. INT. CLASS —- DAY

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Three rhymes, three rhymes per verse. What do you call that? Verses of three lines... Wey?

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: A tercet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: A tercet, very good. And if there were four rhymes, Wey, what would it be?

dialogues.speaker: WEY
dialogues.text: A quatrain.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: A quatrain, it's easy. From “quatre”, four. Tercet, three rhymes. Quatrain, four. How many syllables per line? Can you tell me that? Khoumba?  84.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: I know there are ten.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You know there are ten?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Want me to show you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: “Noir dans la neig-e et dans la brum-e.” That makes ten.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: If you say, “Noir dans la neig-e et dans la brum-e,” you have two extra syllables by counting the mute Es. Don't count them, they're mute. “Noir dans la neige et dans la brume,” that makes eight. If we count precisely, underlining each syllable, we have "ils 6-coutent" - I'll come back to that one - two octosyllables... In the middle of the lesson, Rabah suddenly speaks out to talk about the previous day’s class meeting.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Sir, there’s a problem!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: and one four-syllable line. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Is 11.47 the number of syllables here?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Rounded up, I mean. No, it’s my grade. It’s down!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Can you tell me what that has to do with poetry?

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: They lowered my grade! 11.47 is 11.5.  85.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Who gave you your grade? You shouldn't have it yet, not until you get your reports.

dialogues.speaker: RABAH
dialogues.text: Esmeralda told me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Ah... So the class reps did do something after all, they passed on the grades.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I took a load of notes!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I got the impression you weren't really following the meeting. Louise brandishes a book full of notes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Hey, I wrote all this!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Louise, I'm delighted. You've done a good job passing on information. Let's get back to this poem. The rule is to count in front of a consonant and not in front of a... The two girls look at each other, outraged. As Frangois finishes writing a poem on the board, Souleymane, who doesn’t want to leave things at this, butts in.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Sir, sir, I have a question.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I heard you really wiped me out at the meeting yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Another remark about poetry, I see!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: No, I'm not talking about poetry.  86.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I know you're not talking about poetry. What do you mean, "wiped you out"?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I dunno. You wiped me out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Some people, not me, said if you carry on like this.. Some teachers said if you carry on like this, you'll be in trouble, not "wiped out".

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but that's revenge. I don't get it. Why do all the teachers go for revenge?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What do you mean? What does it have to do with revenge?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: If you say stuff about me getting in trouble and all, that's revenge, right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Revenge has nothing to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, it’s not revenge?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Not at all...

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: It is, it’s revenge.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: We're not on the streets here. It's a warning. Our goal isn't revenge, it's discipline. Get the difference?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: When a judge sends someone to jail, he doesn't do it to get revenge. It's to help society run smoothly.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I call it revenge, you just want to get revenge. You're riffed with me.  87.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind? You think all I care about is revenge? I wake up and say, "I'll get Souleymane today"? Esmeralda reacts immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You say you have other things to do but you insulted him yesterday anyhow. He really laid into you!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No I didn’t, absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: What was it he said, Louise? Louise checks her notes and turns to Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: He said you were "limited". I underlined it, I was so shocked. Souleymane is slightly dazed by this remark. He seems humiliated that such words should have emerged before the whole class.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I’m what? I’m limited? Frangois, startled that Souleymane’s feelings may have been hurt, focuses his anger on the two girls.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Brilliant, brilliant... Esmeralda and Louise, what's your role as class reps exactly? You represent the students to help this class work or you stir up trouble between me and the students? What do you do exactly?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We just do our job, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Wicked! We report on the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. I didn't realize. When I saw you sniggering at the meeting like that, I felt bad, you see? I felt bad for you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reactions 88. FRANgGOIS (CONT'D) It wasn't the place or time to do that. It didn't look very serious, quite frankly, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well nobody minded in any case.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, they did.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Only you!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, no, Esmeralda, it bothered me and I think I can say it bothered the others too.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: No, no, it only bothered you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Sorry, but laughing like that, in the middle of a class meeting, made you look like two skanks.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What? from the class.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Have you just lost it?

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s bad!

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Sir, you can't dump on your students.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: The word is "insult".

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Have you lost it, insulting on us as skanks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, no, you say "dump on" or "insult". It's either one or the other, okay.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, keep on talking.  89.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: In fact, I never said you were skanks. I said that at one point in the meeting you acted like skanks. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Hey, sir, don't try to con us, you said skanks. That's too easy!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, no, I'm not trying to con you, I'm just explaining the difference. You understand what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: No, no, I don’t understand. Souleymane, who has been seething since the start of the discussion, suddenly explodes.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Sir, you don't talk to girls like that! What are you thinking of?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hey, you're going to tell us how to talk to girls, the way you talk to others! You always insult everybody!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: He wants revenge! The old teach is no use now, he wants revenge on the girls!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No way! The noble knight riding to the girls’ rescue won't wash, Souleymane!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: You don't talk to me, man! You don't talk to me like that, wacko!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I told you before, show some respect for your teachers!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I will if I want!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I told you, you're heading for trouble unless you show some respect!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Think you're tough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s not about toughness, it’s about discipline and respect!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I'll take you anytime, man! Souleymane starts putting his things away to avoid looking Frangois in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Hey, cut it out, stop playing the big shot. Calm down! Stop playing the big shot.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Stay outta this!

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Souleymane, cut it out, bro! Fearing that a fight is about to break out, Frangois hurries over.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Hey, don't touch me!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're crazy. You can't just walk out of my class! Are you nuts? 90. Souleymane stands, kicking over his chair that crashes to the floor, and walks over to the door. As he passes, Carl roughly grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Calm down, calm down!

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: Let go of me!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Stop it now! Enough! Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I said let go of me, fucker!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Pathetic... To break free of Carl’s grip, Souleymane tries to hit him with his bag. He miscalculates and strikes Khoumba’s head. She screams as she lifts her hand to her eyebrow that starts bleeding.  gl.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Fuck... Souleymane goes out as Khoumba’s blood forms a puddle on the floor at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up on a sheet of paper on which Frangois starts writing: “Incident report, April 11, 2008”. Frangois is alone in a corner of the deserted staff room. He writes a few words, then breaks off, reads what he has just written, and puts his pen down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principal reads the report attentively as Frangois watches in concern. When he finishes reading, the principal remains silent for a second.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: So, what do we do? I think we need to convene the disciplinary committee, don't we? This is starting to add up. It begins with disrespect, then the fight, with a student injured, and finally he leaves the class without permission.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, but there was only one incident and it all spread out from there. One thing led to another, a chain reaction. The principal stands and concludes:

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Well, what I can do is take a protective measure, since this is so serious, by suspending Souleymane for 48 hours. That'll give us a little time to reach a decision. Shall we do that? However, I need to see you tomorrow. Could you come to my office? That would be better.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Frangois leaves the room.  92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door of the office, Julie, the year supervisor, is waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Frangois! I need a word with you. There's a rumor going around... They continue their conversation as they head along the corridor to the yard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: A rumor?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Some students came to see me and told me.. you insulted them in class.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Who told you that? Louise and Esmeralda, was it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: They told me you called them skanks and that led to the incident with Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: And you go right ahead and believe them?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Yes, well, no.. That's why I needed to see you. You didn't mention it in your incident report so.. yes, I wanted to know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I didn't mention it because I didn't mention it. What can I say?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Did you do it or not?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Did you... (she greets someone who passes) Did you call them skanks?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, but Souleymane's another matter!  93.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I know it had nothing to do with him. But word's getting around. People are talking. I wanted to let you know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for letting me know. Frangois has spoken absently because, out of the window, he has just spotted Esmeralda in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frangois hurries across the yard towards Esmeralda as if he were ready for a fight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Hey, you two. You complained about me to the year supervisor. Thanks a lot! They step away from the other students. Esmeralda, caught off guard, stammers a little.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You could have talked to me about it, couldn’t you? Louise comes over to her friend and joins the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: When a teacher complains about us, he sees the year supervisor, we can do the same thing, right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, it doesn't work both ways. He has raised his voice. A group has formed around them. We notice that Khoumba has a dressing over her eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Of course it’s the same. Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. What were you after by doing this?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: We wanted to see you punished like us!  94.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: To see me punished...

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're going to get me punished?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yes, you insulted us, you get punished!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: And where will that get you, me being punished?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: At least I'll have spoken out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Great, that's a lot of use.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I mean, do you even know what "skank" means?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's not the problem because I never called you skanks!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yes, you did, you called us skanks. For me, skank means prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: It does.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: For me, it doesn't mean that. It's nothing important at all, just a girl laughing stupidly. It’s no worse than that. Esmeralda turns to the circle of girls around her.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Hey, skank means prostitute, right?

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: You bet!  95.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Will Souleymane get expelled? Frangois is caught off his guard. Carl butts

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Of course not.. but...

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Will he get a disciplinary hearing?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: We don't know yet. It's a possibility. Stop yelling before anything's decided.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: It's all settled anyway. We know that!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It isn’t. Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Because. It’s always the same.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I’s always the same!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You know, you're in no position to talk. You're the one who got hurt during the incident.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: So? He didn't mean it. There was a metal thing in his bag.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Whatever happened, he blew a fuse and that's bad. in.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Sir, anyone can blow a fuse.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, they can, but they can calm down after too!

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: That’s not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You calmed down, right?  96.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You're a lot calmer since you got here.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t calmed down. You don’t know me better than I know myself!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All the teachers say your attitude is perfect now. So don't try to pretend otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: So what's the idea? You think you've tamed me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, it doesn't mean we've tamed you. But being sent here by a disciplinary committee helped you understand things, see?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: It didn't help me. I don't understand your shit!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: In making that decision about you, maybe your old teachers wanted to help you and we'll do the same for Souleymane.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Sorry, but I say teachers who expel students are fuckers.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Right on!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Bravo, you want to repeat that?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yeah, they’re fuckers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: This is incredible. Everyone goes wild over some word I said. You say fucker and I shouldn't react?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I don’t give a damn, they’re fuckers!  97.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Hey! You say skanks, we say fucker. You may not like it but it's the same. It's the same!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: First of all, the two words are nothing alike! And if you can't understand that a teacher can say certain things that students can't say, well.. We'll never get anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: We're not allowed to say nothing. We're not allowed to say nothing!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Rubbish! You keep talking all the time! You never stop speaking!

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Whenever we talk, you yell. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Enough! Frangois, at a loose end, leaves the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters the canteen hallway, Khoumba catches up with him. She is alone and looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Sir! Sir!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Tell me, will Souleymane get a hearing or not? Frangois, surprised by the emotion in Khoumba’s voice, turns to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Give it a rest! You sound like you want him to. It fires you up.  98.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Do you know what'll happen if he's expelled?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: He'll change schools.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No, he won't change schools.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: He will, it's automatic. It's obligatory. That goes for Souleymane too.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Do you know his father?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I've seen him once or twice.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No, you don’t know him! If Souleymane is expelled, his dad'll send him back to their village!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Don't get overdramatic.

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: He'll go back to Mali!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I think we all need to keep our heads here. It's okay, don't worry. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frangois comes into the deserted canteen. There are trays on the tables, the leftovers of lunch. He sits down ina He looks a little lost. We find him a little later smoking a cigarette as two WOMEN clear the trays away at the other end of the room, putting them on a trolley. On reaching him, one of them points to Frangois’ cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CLEANING WOMAN
dialogues.text: You can't smoke here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I know, but since I was alone...  99.

dialogues.speaker: CLEANING WOMAN
dialogues.text: The rules hold for everyone. Frangois puts out his cigarette in a dirty plate. The woman takes the tray, glaring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frangois is with the other teachers, talking about Souleymane. Frédéric speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Okay, you went too far with those girls. But we all screw up. It doesn't excuse what Souleymane did.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Listen, Frangois, he's right. I saw Khoumba. Her face was all bloody. What he did is unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: That’s for sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's another thing, her bloody face... His bag hit her by accident. A split eyebrow bleeds a lot. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You can’t ignore it!

dialogues.speaker: HERVE
dialogues.text: Come on, Frangois, don't take it to heart. You've seen how they talk to us?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: How's that relevant? Souleymane is going to get a disciplinary hearing and he'll be expelled.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: That's kind of logical.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So let's talk about that. How many hearings were there last year? Twelve at least.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Not that many.  100.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yes, he could be right.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I know, I'm on the committee so I saw them all. An average of two a month, twelve in all, with an expulsion each time.

dialogues.speaker: HERVE
dialogues.text: Come on, the hearing is where we talk things over. Okay, so twelve students were expelled but maybe there was no other solution.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Twelve out of twelve means there wasn't much of a discussion unfortunately!

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: But twelve out of twelve just means... when a student has a hearing, it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Or that it was justified.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay, things happen that lead to a hearing. But then what happens? What do we expect from a hearing?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: There are all the prior stages. You know that, Frangois. The pre-disciplinary committees, we inform the parents, the students are warned...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Not in this case.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We've no time to.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It’s pretty rare.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It's rare because we know we have this ultimate punishment that allows us to ignore the prior steps. And even if we did use them, the simple fact of expelling a student.. I don't know, it's a disavowal of everything we have tried.  101.

dialogues.speaker: HERVE
dialogues.text: Okay, but at the same time it's Souleymane's chance to justify himself.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Sure! Students at hearings don't speak. They're scared. They're paralyzed. Frangois then decides to use what Khoumba told him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Exactly. Let me sum this up. He'll get a disciplinary hearing, he'll be expelled and maybe even sent back to Mali.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You're being overdramatic.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. Students who know him better than any of us here, who know his father, say that he is likely to send him back to Mali after this.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Some kids are threatened with boarding school but it never happens!

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It can happen!

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Come on, a lot of parents spend their time threatening their kids with that. But you can't take it into account.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Even if there’s just a slight risk that a hearing could lead to him being sent back, I don't think I can take that risk. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It's like when you hesitate over punishing a kid because when he goes home, once that door closes, he'll get a beating from his parents. We've all seen that. But we still have to punish them when they go too far. Whatever the consequences, which don't concern you.  102.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So I ignore that? I know punishment can have such a consequence but I turn a blind eye, I don't want to know, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: No, but I understand...

dialogues.speaker: HERVE
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. You can't take it into account in every case or you won't get anywhere. The violence, him being sent back... True, you have to consider it but after a while...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: No more Christmas presents.. It happens, yes.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Afterwards, it's a question of principle. We each have a role to play. We can't substitute ourselves for the parents.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Sorry, but if I rewind the movie, it's a weird chain of events. It starts with reprimands when Souleymane starts screwing up, forgets his things, or talks back. We punish him. Again and again, until a disciplinary hearing leading to who knows what. Little by little, everything gets out of hand.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: Sure, if you look at it that way, it's really shocking. But, once again, the school won't be expelling Souleymane. He's been gone for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frangois leaves the staff room. He walks along the corridor, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students start to form into their classes as they continue to horse about in the yard.  103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frangois knocks on the door and comes in. The principal doesn’t seem to be very surprised to see him.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Frangois... I didn't expect you so soon. Have you reached a decision?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think I really have much choice. He sits down a little heavily on the chair facing the principal. He doesn't say a word. The principal goes on in a kindly voice.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: By the way, Julie told me you had a heated exchange with two girls in your class.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, the two class reps but it happened first so..

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: You apparently called them "skanks".

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Let's say that, yes.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Well, that complicates things but the problem remains. I'd like you to mention it in your report. I don't want it used against us at the disciplinary hearing. Don't bother hiding it, just write it down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: I'll let you go back over this before we launch the procedure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So I.. I just need to add the...

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, but without going into detail. Does that suit you.  104. Frangois shows no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frangois, alone in the staff room again, rewrites his incident report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tables have been set out in a U-shape in the meeting room. The people come in. PARENTS’ REPS Hello. Hello, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Please sit down. Souleymane and his mother sit on one side, with the two student representatives. The teaching staff sits on another side and the parents’ representatives on the third side of the U. Frangois remains silent and tries in vain to catch Souleymane’s eye. The boy, stubborn, stares at the principal who leads the debate, sitting between Julie, the class supervisor, and the bursar, Monsieur Pierre.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: (to Julie) Can you take the minutes? We fast-forward to the heart of the meeting as the principal reads from Frangois’ report.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: "Carl tried to reason with him and stop him. Souleymane broke free, swinging his bag that hit Khoumba in the face. Then he left, insulting everyone and slamming the door. I didn't go after him because I needed to help Khoumba whose eyebrow was bleeding." Those are the facts that led to today's hearing. Madame, it doesn't mean Souleymane is a bad boy. That's not what we're saying. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But, sometimes, a student in a class, through voluntary or involuntary behavior, can create an atmosphere that prevents the class from working and getting ahead. (Souleymane translates) Do you understand what we're saying?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: If I may say something, it's true that there had been a number of signs that should have warned us. We could have reacted sooner. But now we have to deal with an incident that is fairly violent and that's simply unacceptable. I'd like to know if you realize that, Souleymane?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You see, we're not saying you're deliberately violent. The problem is you can't control what you say and what you do.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Souleymane, we'd like to hear you. You're here to express your point of view. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn. I've got nothing to say. Do whatever you want to do. His mother says something in Malian. She seems to be telling him off for his aggressive reaction to the teachers’ accusations.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Excuse Mme... Souleymane’s mother continues to speak in Malian.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Can you translate?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: She says I'm a good boy. I do my homework. I help my brothers and sisters with their work when I can. I always wash the dishes and help her when I can.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Madam, we don't doubt that Souleymane is a good son. That's not the problem. I'd like to get back to his school record.  106. PARENTS’ REP #1 Excuse me, but could we focus on the facts here? Firstly, I'd like to say that we're surprised to see the teacher involved in the incident on this committee. We find that highly irregular. BURAK’S MOTHER (another parents’ rep) It's true. It's odd to be both judge and litigant.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: First of all, Mr. Marin was elected to the administrative board as the teachers' representative. Moreover, I think that the incident that occurred in Mr. Marin's class doesn't involve the teacher directly. PARENTS’ REP #1 I'm sorry, but you mention some harsh words spoken by the teacher. Apparently, if I understand rightly, you used the word "skanks" to describe the class reps. And that's a problem.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I did say that but it wasn't something that concerned Souleymane. I think he used the excuse of a rather heated exchange with those two students to express the bad mood he was in that day. PARENTS’ REP #1 He tried to defend them. So I feel that it's relevant. Frangois, awkward, prefers not to reply while Frédéric, annoyed, answers for him.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERIC
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but absolutely nothing justifies being disrespectful to a teacher, insulting everyone and leaving a class without permission.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Souleymane, do you have anything to say?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: I don't know. What can I say?  107. SOULEYMANE’S MOTHER Sir, madame... She then continues in Malian.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Souleymane?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: What did your mother say?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: The same thing as before. His mother says something else in Malian.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Yes, Souleymane?

dialogues.speaker: SOULEYMANE
dialogues.text: She apologizes on my behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Souleymane and his mother sit down on a bench in the corridor. They don’t speak or even look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meeting room, the vote is under way. Everyone taking part in the meeting drops a small piece of paper into a box that is passed around. Everyone is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The year supervisor comes to fetch Souleymane and his mother who are still in the same position.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: You can come back in now. They stand and follow her into the room. As soon as they sit down, the principal starts speaking.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Madame, the committee has conferred and has decided to expel Souleymane from the school for good. You will receive the ruling by registered mail and have eight days to appeal. We shall do our best to find Souleymane another school.  108. Souleymane translates for his mother who stands and picks up her bag. SOULEYMANE’S MOTHER Goodbye, sir, madame... Souleymane too stands and goes out with looking back as the principal continues to address him.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Souleymane, come to see me before the end of the week, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Souleymane and his mother cross the yard to the exit. From the window, Frangois watches them go. INT. CLASS —- DAY For the students’ final class, the atmosphere is relaxed. We can sense that the tension of the year has eased. The students are like actors after a show. Frangois invites the students to weigh up the past year: what they have learned, what they particularly liked.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Mathematical proportionality.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: This year, you learned mathematical proportionality. All right.

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: I liked science.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What you learned, not what you liked. If you liked it, you learned. So what did you learn in science?

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: All about volcanoes, earthquakes, plates... Convergence and divergence, movement of the Earth's plates... It was fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: It interested you?

dialogues.speaker: BURAK
dialogues.text: Yeah.  109.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: Well, in mathematics, trigonometry, Pythagoras' theorem, Thalés' theorem...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: I'll stop you there. You can't sit there and brag you learned Pythagoras' theorem. Recite it for us.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: If, in a triangle.. two sides are equal to.. If the square root.. If the square of two sides is equal to the square... the square of the hypotenuse... then the triangle's a right-angled triangle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: More or less, yes.

dialogues.speaker: BOUBACAR
dialogues.text: It's spot on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: All right. If you say so, I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELICA
dialogues.text: In history, I learned about triangular trade. The fact that ships left Europe with manufactured goods that they took to Africa to trade for men who'd become slaves that they took to America to work. Then they took the money they made back to Europe. That's triangular trade.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Chemistry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What in chemistry?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Combustion.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Okay and what's that?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Blending Fehling's solution and glucose.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What do you get?  110.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Heat up the test-tube and it changes color.

dialogues.speaker: _ FRANCOIS /
dialogues.text: What's the interest in knowing that?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: The interest in knowing that? I dunno. Why teach it to us if there's no interest?

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: Reproduction.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What did you learn about human reproduction, for instance?

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: Human reproduction... Well, the sperm gets into the ovum, then you wait 9 months, then you do a sonogram and then it comes out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: The sperm does?

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: No, the human being that's inside.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Khoumba?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Yes. That is your name?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Yes. In music, I learned to play the alto recorder... and in Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You learned to play the recorder in Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: No, in music, I learned to play the alto recorder. And I learned other stuff in Spanish.  111.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Very good. Can you say something to us in Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: Llegan las vacaciones.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: And that means?

dialogues.speaker: KHOUMBA
dialogues.text: It's the vacation soon or the vacation's coming.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: I didn't learn anything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You can't spend 9 months at school and not learn anything.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: You can, I'm the living proof.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You got something from the books we read.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Your books are shite.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: They're what?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: They're useless.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: What about a book you read by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: A book I read? Well, there's "The Republic". The book "The Republic".

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: “The Republic” by Plato?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: You read that? How come you read that?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: My big sister had it.  112.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: She does philosophy?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: No, law.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: So what's it about?

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
dialogues.text: Well, there's this guy...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCOIS
dialogues.text: Socrates, his name's Socrates.

dialogues.speaker: ESMERALDA
